Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Development of Adaptable Web Modules to Stimulate Active Learning in Hydrology using Data and Model Simulations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project is creating case-based, web-enabled educational hydrology modules that encapsulate real-world hydrologic systems. This project expands on the results of a Type I CCLI pilot study and grounds the learning experiences using three large-scale natural hydrologic systems (Coastal Louisiana, the Florida Everglades, and the Great Salt Lake Basin in Utah).

Intellectual Merit: The project leverages recent research advances on monitoring and modeling of complex natural systems and synthesizes them to develop a suite of flexible, adaptable web-based modules. The selected natural systems, each presenting some unique concepts and physical settings, contribute to redefining the teaching of hydrology by focusing on the dynamics of fundamental hydrologic processes and their connections to climate drivers, ecosystems' response, and water resources operational constraints. An extensive set of interactive learning modules is being built into the system and is supported by an instructional interface, an instructor's guide, and a set of implementation and adaptation procedures. The project adopts an improvement-focused evaluation model with an iterative design process which includes multiple iterations of design, implementation, evaluation, and redesign.

Broader Impacts: To facilitate wide dissemination and adaptability, the system is being implemented using open source geospatial web technologies and community-based tools for data publication and analysis. The architecture of the system supports the addition of future hydrologic applications developed by other members of the hydrologic educational community. The participating institutions include a primarily African American institution, a college for women, a primarily Hispanic institution, and a minority high school. Through a design-based research approach, the project is identifying and implementing successful strategies so that the innovations can be scaled and adapted in diverse settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Given their social impact, mitigating the impacts of droughts and floods has been a central goal of hydrologic engineering. In the United States, and in the world, these two factors dominate all other hazards in terms of their impact on human life and economic development. As the global climate varies, where and how often extreme floods and droughts happen varies systematically. Today, we understand that such variations in the intensity, location and frequency of floods and droughts are determined to a great extent by organization in the way climate evolves. For instance, the El Nino Southern Oscillation leads to distinct areas being flooded while others suffer drought over much of the world. The North Atlantic Oscillation and the Pacific Decadal Oscillation lead to similar impacts with recurrence of 10-20 years respectively. Traditional instruction on hydrology has not included training on assessing the effects of such climate phenomena into the impacts on regional hydrology and hence on agriculture, urban areas, ecology, public health and the economy. The goal of this subaward was to develop hands on teaching materials that could provide an effective example of the importance of considering such information, with a case study centered on S. Florida, a climate sensitive region with a number of cities, agriculture, and a National Park that are susceptible to droughts and floods that pose a significant management challenge.

Teaching materials were developed on an electronic, web based platform that allow students to access actual data sources specific to any region in the USA that they may be interested in to perform and interpret hands on analyses as to the potential for how different aspects of climate may influence the hydrology of their region. These were integrated into instruction in the classes taught using Hydroviz, and contribute to the undergraduate STEM curriculum, and could also be used by high school instructors and students as part of an Earth Science curriculum.

Taking advantage of an emerging El Nino event, a secial interdisciplinary class on the potential Water related impacts and their management was organized at Columbia University and the students engaged in directed research using the tools developed as well as additional work with experts at Columbia University as well as water managers in California, Florida, and other locations. The student response to this immersive learning experience was very positive, and the external experts also appreciated the engagement with the highly motivated students.
